discussion.content:
IoC becomse visible after IoA
IoC is as early as it can be, 
IoE will show exposed vulnerabilites but not an attack at init stage

Selected Answer: D
IoC comes after IoA

questions.question_text: Which among the following is used by anti-malware systems and threat intelligence platforms to spot and stop malicious activities at an initial stage?
Which risk management phase helps in establishing context and quantifying risks?

discussion.content:
Circuit-Level Gateway Firewalls
A circuit-level firewall is responsible for verifying the TCP handshakes of incoming traffic. It works at the OSI session layer, which falls between the transport and presentation layers (both of which are beneath the application layer).
and I think it's option A

questions.question_text: Which firewall technology can be implemented in all (application, session, transport, network, and presentation) layers of the OSI model?

discussion.content:
answer C.
Mobile content management (MCM) or mobile information management (MIM) solutions provide secure access to corporate data on smartphones, tablets, and other mobile devices 
cdn book page 850

questions.question_text: Michelle is a network security administrator working at a multinational company. She wants to provide secure access to corporate data (documents, spreadsheets, email, schedules, presentations, and other enterprise data) on mobile devices across organizations networks without being slowed down and also wants to enable easy and secure sharing of information between devices within an enterprise. Based on the above-mentioned requirements, which among the following solution should Michelle implement?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
From practice questions given by EC_Council

This should be A. EFS.

From the CND eBook page 1167: "EFS provides file system-level encryption in Windows (starting from Windows 2000), except the home version."

BitLocker provides disk level encryption. See page 1148.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a Windows in-built feature that provides filesystem-level encryption in the OS (starting from Windows 2000), except the Home version of Windows?
